She really did spend a lot of her time thinking about other people, about her constituents in Dunkley, about her colleagues and their kids, about people who struggle against entrenched disadvantage in this country and about people affected by the terrible cancer that she took on with such incredible forbearance and style.

I had the privilege in the middle of last year of doing a leadership development course with Peta and a number of colleagues through the work of the McKinnon Foundation—the member for Berowra was part of that. It involved an in-residence week of work together in New South Wales. As that experience was a bit like a grown-up school camp, it inevitably brought us closer together. Peta's husband, Rod Glover, was one of the principal designers and convenors of the program, which was to our enormous benefit because there are few people in Australia with Rod's expertise, experience and deep humanity when it comes to public policy and government and how important those things are. Characteristic of her approach to life, Peta was not going to be coy about the challenge of being in a course in which Rod was effectively one of the teachers.

By the end of the course, when we were doing some final sessions by Zoom, Peta was in New York as a parliamentary representative to the United Nations General Assembly, and I remember one occasion when Peta and Rod had stayed up into the wee hours of the morning to be part of a McKinnon discussion, each from their own device and each in separate rooms in the same apartment in New York. We were only 10 minutes into the session when Peta interrupted the fairly serious proceedings to say, 'Rod, do you reckon you could close your door so that I don't have to deal with the echo from down the hall?'

Clearly, among the many things that made Peta and Rod best friends and life partners, was the fact that they have in common the highest quality of commitment to excellence in public service, governance and democracy. I'll tell you what: the world needs more of that, now more than ever. In Peta's case, that commitment to her work as a parliamentarian meant seeking outcomes that were defined by fairness, shared wellbeing and sustainability, but it also meant practising politics in a way that was defined by a sense of duty and honour and conducted in a way that was guided by principle and respect. Peta absolutely lived that approach all day, every day.

What's more? She was an agent of cooperation and collegiality, a person who brought people into the conversation together and shaped that conversation so that we could agree more often and so that we could disagree better. The Prime Minister used the term 'happy warrior' this morning, which I think says a lot, and many others in this debate have acknowledged that aspect of Peta, which was due to not just her natural ability but also her concerted focus and work ethic.

I wish I'd had the chance to have a hit of squash with Peta. I love the game of squash. I love sport. I know the particular way in which people's nature can be expressed through the skill, craft, effort and creativity of the games they've applied themselves to and loved for a long time. I know that Peta would have taught me some lessons on the squash court—from what others have said, quite probably hard lessons! There were plenty of areas in which you could learn a lot from Peta Murphy. Indeed, there is an opportunity for all of us in reflecting on what was special about Peta to carry those qualities forward in our lives and our work here together. It can never hurt to remember that time is short, that we're privileged to serve our communities and our country in this place and that there is no limit on the capacity of thoughtfulness, fierce principle and generosity of spirit to make a difference. Vale, Peta Murphy.

Mr GOSLING (Solomon) (20:05): My memories of Peta Murphy will be of her always smiling and fighting for what she believed in—all through her health battles, always caring for her community, her colleagues and our great country. She was warm, generous, strong and proud of heart; a great Labor warrior who had other opportunities but who wanted to serve here in this place. That was even after the electoral defeat in her first time running for this place. I can relate to that, because I had been in a similar position to Peta in 2013; but I know that what drove her was to get to this place to make a difference for our country.

When I was elected as a new MP in 2016 I met Peta in her role as a staff member in this place, working for Brendan O'Connor, the member for Gorton. I remember just how much of an awesome operator she was. As the member for Shortland also reflected on, she was fierce and didn't suffer any BS. She was fiercely loyal to Brendan; she was very protective but very insightful and intelligent, able to distil the policy pros and cons of anything that was put to her. She was very clearly an awesome staff member but also really knew her stuff, and there was no doubt in my mind when I met her that at the next election she would be elected—no doubt at all—because of all those qualities that so many people have spoken about tonight.

As many have done, I re-read her maiden speech to this parliament when she was elected in 2019. While I won't quote Pippi Longstocking again, although I will share those quotes and Peta's speech with my daughter, there were other themes in Peta's speech that I thought I might reflect on briefly because they also resonated with me. Not only was it an incredibly brave speech but, in a really clear-eyed way, she spoke of the nature of politics, which often:
… mistakes aggressiveness for advocacy, which demands certainty and rejects reflection as weakness, and which is quick to judge and slow to forgive.
She spoke of us in this place as custodians of Australia's national conversation, saying:
Politics is a place where ideas should be contested. They should be contested with a passion. They should be contested fiercely, robustly and forcefully. … But how we do that matters.
She spoke of the return of her cancer and exhorted all of us to undertake the required health checks.
Peta was a warrior for women: for women's rights and for women's health. But she said other things in that first speech, also. She said:
Men, stop ignoring what your body's telling you.

The health stats for Australian men in our community emphasise how important her advocacy was. We need to ensure that the resources are in place to support our community members to actively care for their health. I just wanted to point that out. Many speakers have focused on her incredible work in the battle against breast cancer, but she was concerned about everyone. Further, she said:

Commit to the reform and funding that our health system needs and do whatever is required to ensure that Australia trains, retains and invests in the healthcare professionals and researchers who make our system great. We owe it to our community to do that.
Those themes are worth remembering, among the many causes she supported and the issues that drove Peta and the work she did for her community and for the country while she was in this place.

My and my family's deepest condolences go to Peta's husband. I really wish you all the best, Rod. I also want to wish the best to her parents, Bob and Jan, and to all her family, all her friends and the community that she so loyally, enthusiastically, intelligently and passionately served. In particular, tonight, I send love and prayers to those who are currently fighting cancer—those in my electorate and those around the nation—and may be hearing these words or seeing today's contributions. I wish you good results. I wish you remission and much, much more time with your loved ones. As Peta said, you are not alone. May Peta Murphy rest in eternal peace.

Dr CHARLTON (Parramatta) (20:12): I hadn't met Peta Murphy before I arrived in parliament. I was aware of her, of course. I knew that she was one of the bright young Labor MPs who had won a seat from the Liberals in 2019, and I knew that she was the history-making first woman to represent the seat of Dunkley, but I didn't get to know her properly until I was elected and, in the mysterious wisdom of the whips, allocated a seat beside her in the chamber. As bench mates go, I lucked out. Peta was generous with her knowledge of the parliament, constantly giving me a running commentary of the play-by-play—what was happening and why. As a new MP, sitting next to Peta was like the experience of sitting next to Rabs Warren on the hill at Leichhardt Oval. She explained to me everything that was happening. She shared the hidden context of the parliamentary machinations, which is often lost on new MPs, and explained the nuances of things that had gone on in previous parliaments and were being referred to in this one.

I've sat next to or in front of Peta for almost all of my time in the parliament, and, as a bench mate, Peta was mostly just lots of fun. We sat here on the 'bend', as Peta called it, and these benches suited her, I think. We're far enough away from the camera shot that you don't have to behave too much but close enough to be right in the action. And Peta was always in the action. Of course, sitting in the chamber of the Australian parliament is a great privilege, and Peta showed me what it meant to recognise that privilege. When she sat on that bench, she was totally absorbed in the contest. She quipped, interjected, joked, heckled and followed the meaning, significance and import of every moment.

Sure, she was occasionally doing Wordle, fervently eliminating vowels and consonants and occasionally swearing when she didn't get it in five. But, every moment, she was paying attention, analysing every point, parsing every turn and never letting a word of untruth or a statement she felt was sexist pass without her comment or interjection. Sitting next to her felt like being in the political moment, recognising the importance of the forum. In all the hours we sat next to each other talking, interjecting, laughing and shouting, there was one thing that she never did. She never complained about her illness—not one word. She never revealed the pain she must have been in, and she never spoke of her own discomfort. Just last week, when she was in the parliament, I told her how we'd missed her and asked her how she was. She smiled, said she was fine and sat down in her seat. Her response to her illness was a testament to her character and to courage in the face of adversity—thinking always about what she can do for others, not herself.

And so it's with deep sadness and regret that I acknowledge the passing of a wonderful Australian, a parliamentarian admired on both sides of the aisle for her strength and courage, someone who saw and felt the impact of intergenerational disadvantage and battled against it every day, putting every ounce of her being into fighting for the underdog. We offer our condolences to Peta's husband of 24 years, Rod Glover; her parents, Bob and Jan; and her siblings. We're all richer for having known her. May she rest in peace.

Ms SCRYMGOUR (Lingiari) (20:17): Like everyone in this place that's risen to speak on this condolence motion for Peta Murphy, I rise with a heavy heart but a real sense of privilege that I get an opportunity to speak about the passing of someone who was a dear friend to people in this chamber and also a colleague. The member for Dunkley was a special member of this parliament and our Labor family. The tributes from all sides of politics are testament to this. I was sitting in Alice Springs when it came over the news. I must admit to being absolutely floored. Like the member for Parramatta, I remember that we hadn't seen her at our caucus meeting on Tuesday. Then she came back here, and I went up to Peta, asked how she was and said that many of us had missed her presence here.

When I was a new member—I came here in 2022—this woman, full of energy and intellect, took the time to sit down with me, single me out and have a conversation, particularly about First Nations issues. She welcomed me to this place. I realised, through those conversations, that she and I shared many friends across the legal community and people that she'd worked with. Over the last couple of days, since her death on Monday, I've been contacted by a lot of those lawyers that had worked with her at the Victorian Bar and people that I've known for a long time as well. So there was that connection.

But there was also another connection with Peta which was really important for me, having watched and cared for my sister through her battle with breast cancer. In my family, I'm one of eight, and to suddenly have one of my sisters be diagnosed with breast cancer and to go through that journey and not really understand what that journey was going to be—it was quite profound. It was great to be able to talk to Peta because I didn't realise just what my sister was experiencing. But Peta was able to provide a lot of information and insight into that, and I was grateful because I was able to provide that to my sister.

I know that Minister Husic talked before about the Breast Cancer Network, and I also want to acknowledge the Jane McGrath nurses because I saw firsthand, when my sister was going through her treatment for breast cancer, the Jane McGrath nurses and the important role that they played with not just the breast cancer sufferer but also their familyand how they worked through that.

It is hard to imagine a more principled, caring and determined woman and member of this parliament. There was something truly special in the way Peta set about her work and how she stood so firm in her beliefs and her inner advocacy of others. I didn't get to work with Peta for long, but what was apparent from the moment I met her was that there was this woman who was a leader and a member of parliament who cared deeply about many of the issues. Her grace, her strength and her absolute commitment to serving the people of not only Dunkley but also Australia is something I will hold with me for a long time.

There are few people who could have done what Peta did. Knowing how unwell she was and knowing that her body was growing sicker, Peta worked relentlessly in pursuit of a better country. She did her duty to the people of Dunkley in a way that most politicians can only dream of. It takes a truly unique type of person to stay true to what they believe, and that's exactly what Peta did. It is hard to believe that it was just a week ago, while we were all here for sittings, that I had my last conversation with Peta. It reminds me to make the most of every single day in this parliament and to fight, as fearlessly as she did, for my community.

While her cancer did not define her, Peta was a staunch advocate for those who are facing the battle of breast cancer and, as I said, provided a lot of insight and support to me so that I could provide that support to my sister. While it was a personal battle she fought, she provided a focus in this place on the work that needs to be done, and that is something that now falls to all of us.

We all know that Peta had a profound impact not only on this parliament but also on so many others. Some of Peta's former colleagues and some of the best legal minds in this country have reached out to me to share their sense of loss. Peta, as they all said, was not only a great solicitor but someone who always put her convictions into her work and whose convictions drove her to do what was right. This type of combination is a powerful one, and it shines through in the many tributesthat many of those who worked with her have made.

I just want to read, very quickly, one of those emails and comments, which I got from a QC in Victoria that had worked for a long time with Peta when she was at the Victorian Bar. He said: 'Marion, when you speak about Peta, we're all shocked, actually, and quite despondent. Here's what we would like people to know about Peta's life before politics. She was tireless and fearless in her advocacy as a trial lawyer. Her clients were, typically, underprivileged and, sometimes, extremely politically unpopular. In the wake of the 9/11 attacks in New York and Washington, she represented accused persons in some of the early antiterrorism cases, a fact which was ultimately deployed against her by her political opponents, yet she was driven by her commitment to the rule of law'—and I know that there are many lawyers in this place who know exactly what that means—'and a deep belief in the integrity of the Australian justice system. Her successful work for the Tamil leadership at the height of the Sri Lankan Civil War established her as a heroine amongst the Tamil diaspora. Her many lawyers and people in Victoria, who know her and who were devoted to her, will miss her terribly.'

I got to know Rod in the many conversations that I had with him in relation to the McKinnon Institute. Many of us have risen and mentioned Rod. All of us in this place know that this job isn't easy on our families, but it is particularly hard on our partners. Rod, even in the short time I knew Peta—and I've known you for this small time—it is obvious the tremendous bond that the two of you had. To her parents, her sisters and her family, my heart is with you.

What I hope is that Peta's legacy in this parliament is one that we all hold close in all the work that we do. Peta worked every day to make this a better place and to fight for her community. It has been an honour to serve with her and with all the members in this parliament, particularly my colleagues. When we heard about this, I sent an email out, particularly to my colleagues from Victoria, who I know were certainly hurting. Peta, it has been a privilege to stand here, to serve with you, to learn from you and to know you. May she rest in peace.

Ms ROBERTS (Pearce) (20:26): I stand here with no notes. I started to write a speech, and the words wouldn't come down onto the paper. I kept writing and scribbling it out, and more words and more emotions came forward, so I thought, 'I'm going to stand on my feet, and I'm just going to speak.' Peta always used to say to me: 'Tracey, just speak. Just speak what you're thinking. It's great!' And I used to say: 'I can't do that. I'm in federal parliament.' She'd say, 'Just do it!' So, Peta, I am doing this for you, sweetheart.

I stand here and I feel an amazing sense of emotion but incredible pride for a beautiful lady—a lady with such heart and such tenacity. I remember when I very first came into parliament and sat here. I had Julian Hill here, who was my booth buddy at the time. Peta came up to me, and she said, 'You sat next to Julian Hill,' and I said, 'Yes.' She said, 'Good luck!' I said, 'Okay,' thinking, 'What does she mean?' About twenty minutes after that, I realised what she meant! But Julian was an amazing booth buddy.

Peta and I bonded. She was an incredibly caring person—wonderful, just knowledgeable. Her wisdom was intense, but her reach, to show how much she cared for people and supported people, was unparalleled.

We used to talk a lot, and I used to say to her after each session: 'Peta, how did that go? Did it sound okay?' She'd say, 'Tracey, you were great!' She was so assuring and so caring. One of the things about Peta is that she was like Jekyll and Hyde. She had this most amazing, beautiful, caring, nurturing personality that loved and cared for everybody, and then she had this ferocious tenacity and a cheeky personality that just fired up. The facial expressions—I'll never forget those facial expressions. Trying to keep your face straight in parliament when Peta turned around and looked at you with one of those incredible facial expressions—you just wanted to burst into laughter. And you can't, because the cameras are everywhere. So, Peta, thank you for that. Trying to keep a straight face was really difficult.

But there was her knowledge and hand-holding. When we first started last year, when we first came into parliament a little bit nervous and a little bit tense, she was just a beautifully caring person. I think each and every one of us in the class of '22 will agree with that.

Her care for her community—how she absolutely understood and knew what was needed and how she reached out to nearly every single individual in Dunkley—was just beyond me. She knew everything about everybody, about the sporting clubs, the seniors groups, the residents association, the business associations, the people doing it tough and the people doing really well—everybody. She cared for each and every one of them. She worked incredibly hard in this place to make sure that the legislation would support her community. Her sporting prowess, her passion—I just think about this all bundled up in one person, in just one beautiful person who was so caring but so tenacious.

If the opposition said anything that she thought was out of line—whoa!—she'd have a go. But she was really smart and never got caught by the Speaker. There's a knack to that. Without a doubt, there's a definite knack to that. That used to amuse me too. The Speaker used to look up and she'd stop. Everybody else sitting behind her would be smiling, and we'd get glared at. I'm standing here—and that's where Peta sat. I remember not that long ago saying to her, 'The collar on your shirt could do with a pull before question time,' and she said, 'Why don't you come and straighten it for me?' I said, 'Why would I do that?' because you couldn't see it from that side; it was only from this side that you could see. She said, 'There might be cameras at the back!' There are no cameras at the back. She had that amazing personality, that really good sense of humour.

When we realised that we were both breast cancer survivors, that took us on another journey of connection. We discussed the treatment, the cancer, the medical profession and the need for investment in research so that nobody would have to die of cancer. We discussed what would need to be done and how we could basically put an end to this, how we could help support the breast cancer care group and the Cancer Council research. We talked about what was needed, the fundraising, what fundraising we'd done—'What treatment did you have?' The people around us—every single person is touched by cancer in one way or the other. Our journeys ran parallel. We were diagnosed at a very similar time and we were in remission at a very similar time. It's just heartbreaking that Peta's battle was lost. It's so unfair because she was such a vibrant, beautiful person with so much to give to her community, so much to give to everybody around her and so much to give to her family.

Her fur babies had Sesame Street names—I love it—Bert and Ernie. I can just imagine them doing something wrong in the street: 'Bert! Ernie! Come here!'' There were stories that she told about her fur babies, and I love my fur babies too, so we had a lot of conversations about that.

For her husband, Rod, of 24 years, imagine an absolute pocket rocket, a dynamo of a person, and now facing that loss of her not being here. We feel it here, in this parliament. The community of Dunkley will be feeling it, and her family—her mum and dad and her sisters—and her staff. It's just a void; it's a very difficult void. I look here and I think, 'Where is she, our beautiful person?' You expect her to come bouncing in, and she's not going to come bouncing in. She's not coming back. It's really difficult to grasp because she was such a fighter. She deserved to be still walking; she deserved to be still sitting here. I just think that is so very sad.

Our Prime Minister supported her every step of the way. You see the Prime Minister—you see the face of the Prime Minister—but you don't see the heart of our Prime Minister, our ministers and our team. They put that caring hug continually around her so that she felt supported, she felt nurtured and she felt loved in this place. We get criticised from elsewhere and by other people, but there's such a strong bond within us that we genuinely care for one another. You kick one and the rest of us limp, because that's who we are. We are federal Labor. We're the Albanese Labor government. We care, we've got hearts, and that heartbeat is well and truly showing for Peta.

It was just a couple of weeks ago, a few weeks ago, that we were sitting here. I remember looking at the back of her head, and I said, 'Peta, your hair's looking amazing. You're starting to look really curly,' because I was like the keeper of the hair. Since I got into trouble about the collar at the back, I was mindful about it. So I said, 'Your hair looks amazing.' She came to me afterwards, she touched me on the arm, and she said, 'Tracey.' I said, 'What?' She said, 'It looks great, doesn't it?' I said, 'It looks really good. It's growing.' She said the words, 'Not for long.' I looked at her and I didn't know what to say, and she just shook her head. I couldn't speak, because, when she looked at me and I looked in her eyes, I knew what she meant. I knew that more treatment would be coming, and she didn't have that joie de vivre and that fight. She had that calmness about her. In the cancer wards, when you see people who've got that calmness, it's always a bit distressing for people to observe and see that. She was right. Her hair did go, and she wasn't 'for long'.

I want to read out to you what I put on my Facebook. I couldn't do it that same day, because, once again, I was trying to get the words together. I don't know if anybody ever reads Facebook in parliament, but I'm going to abuse the privilege. I'm very sorry; I apologise. This is what I wrote:

There are some people in this world who you meet for the first time and you instantly bond. You feel like you've known them forever. This is how I felt last year when I met the beautiful Peta Murphy, a hard working, dedicated member of parliament. A strong, determined advocate for her beloved electorate of Dunkley. Today I cried! I'm devastated about the passing of our loyal friend, mentor, adviser and warrior. She was an absolute champion for breast cancer survivors! Her passing will impact on many of us who saw her fearless fight against the big C. She gave it her all with courage and determination. A true inspiration. My heart goes out to her husband, Rod; her parents, siblings and friends who are now heartbroken and trying to come to terms with the loss of such a vibrant, opinionated, bundle of love and fun! I will miss our chats, her positive energy and her compelling, nurturing focus on making sure everyone felt cared for and that nobody was left behind. Peta, your intelligence, love and kindness touched all who knew you. Rest in peace, gorgeous girl, you already are and always will be missed beyond measure.
God bless, beautiful girl.

Mr RAE (Hawke) (20:37): Like many of my colleagues today, I don't have a prepared speech. I've got a few scribbled notes. I'll try and avoid reading from my Facebook, but I'm glad Tracey did because that was so beautiful. I think I might be the only former campaign director in the room—apologies if that's wrong—but I will let you in on a little secret about—I'm sorry, Mr Speaker; I'm not the only former campaign director in the room. While the Speaker sits quietly in the chair and judges, I'll let you in on a little secret amongst campaign directors. New candidates, you think very rarely of the campaign directors, but we think a lot about you. We spend a lot of time thinking about you. There are particular candidates that we spend more time thinking about. It's just a structural reality of electoral politics. In any given election, depending on the type of election that it is, we spend a lot of time thinking about candidates in particular seats, especially if those seats form part of the path to victory for our given party. Then, we also spend quite a lot of time thinking about particular candidates who stand out in such a way that they could be, in and of themselves, the difference in an election—the difference that could determine who forms government in this most important of places.

For two elections, Peta Murphy took up a lot of my thinking. I spent a lot of time thinking about Peta Murphy. One of the other things that I think are rightly kept somewhat quiet is that we know a lot more about you than you would hope. You candidates are pretty heavily vetted. In doing that, there's a strange, almost perverse, understanding of a person that you come to—without their knowledge and without their interaction with that process. You have this very intimate understanding of a human being through the collation of all the information that you can get about them and their life—their vulnerabilities, their ambitions, the things that they'd like to achieve, the way they would like to contribute.

Through two elections I spent a lot of time gathering information about Peta Murphy. She was running in a critically important seat, the seat of Dunkley, a seat that had traditionally been held by conservative members and a seat in which there had never been a female member. It was a seat that was very difficult for us to win. The part of the seat that Peta lived in, came from, is more Labor inclined, but it's balanced to the south by Mount Eliza, which Peta would agree most certainly wasn't. So Peta Murphy, from a distance, both in 2016 and then in 2019, occupied a lot of my thoughts, because she was clearly an exceptional human being—and so many people here today have explored that.

What was so clear to us was her values were lived in every moment of her working life through her work in the broader social justice space. She moved into her legal career, working in the Victorian justice system, the community legal centre, working in Victorian Legal Aid. These were enormous contributions from a young lawyer to her community and to our state and country. That culminated with her, obviously, becoming a barrister. Looking at her, you see she had the values that our party so badly wanted to bring to this place in each of those elections. Obviously we were unsuccessful in 2016. In 2019, it wasn't an election that went the way that the Labor Party necessarily wanted it to go, more broadly, but there were two shining lights in Victoria out of that election: the election of the now member for Corangamite, who is a fantastic member, and the election of the member for Dunkley. On that night that was so difficult for so many people across our party and movement, so many of us in the campaign wing of the organisation took considerable solace in the election of these people. For me, the election of Peta was a great redeeming element of what had otherwise been a very disappointing process.

She was elected, of course, with a broader group in that 2019 election, and I can hear from the contributions of others—and of course from many of my friends in this place, from whom I knew this already—that Peta was immediately embraced for the person that she was. She was passionate and compassionate. She was fierce, she was inspiring and she was loyal. We've heard from so many people today that those qualities were so deeply appreciated by her colleagues in this place, a place that can be lonely and can be isolating and can be difficult to form and maintain friendships in over long periods of time. Peta's values guided the way that she conducted herself, the way that she approached her work and the way that she approached her relationships with others in this place. In that manner she was a constant, she was reliable and she was, as I said, deeply inspiring.

One of the things that have been touched on today that were so impressive about Peta's work—and there are many things that we could draw on from her time here in this place—was her commitment and her approach to exploring viable, practical ways to deal with gambling and gaming reform in our country, which was so admirable. She understood that the issue of problem gambling was an issue that disproportionately affected communities like her own. Yet she was not a person so divorced from that community that she necessarily wanted to pursue an impractical, ideological approach, so she led a broader cross-section of this parliament to explore the policy approaches that might truly be implemented, that might truly drive the reform that was needed in order to deal with that specific problem-gambling element and all of the insidious parts of the industry that underpin it. As we know, she brought down that report, worked with people all across the parliament, from all different political backgrounds, and delivered the road map to reform in a way that no-one has previously been able to do. We know that this is a set of recommendations and a piece of thinking, public policy analysis and consideration that the government is looking at very closely at the moment.

One of the matters that have come up regularly today is Peta's attendance in parliament last week. I sit behind her—sat behind her—and always enjoyed being in here with her. Particularly when things were difficult, she had a way of dissecting the challenges of the debate while, at the same time, making what could be challenging times bearable in this place, and she conducted herself with the same incredible strength and dignity, here in the chamber and outside of it, that we all knew her for. For a new member like me, it was and has been deeply inspiring, and I respected her immensely in those moments and all the others.

Those of us who serve in this parliament, from any party and any background, are incredibly lucky, deeply privileged people to be chosen by our communities to come here to represent their hopes and their ambitions. For those of us that do, the hope and the ambition is that, in that incredible fortune that is bestowed upon us, we can serve our communities in such a way that they might also become lucky that we do. And that is not the same, or not certain, for all of us. Peta Murphy was the type of representative of her community—and, indeed, a representative in this place for all of Australia—that the people of Dunkley and the people of Australia are very lucky to have had. She conducted herself with integrity. She was compassionate, she always pursued what she believed was right and, as she set out to do, she most certainly left this place a much better place than when she came into it.

Mr PERRETT (Moreton) (20:47): I'm proud, I guess—if that's the right word—to speak on the loss of the wonderful member for Dunkley, the great Peta Murphy. I particularly pass on my condolences to Rod and to all of her staff: to Lauren Johnson, Madison Child, John Conlon, Kitty McLoughlin, Madeleine Van Der Zypp, Louis Robson and particularly Majella Frick, who is a sister of a branch member that I have—in fact, I went to a branch meeting with her last night—so we have often talked about Peta Murphy and the journey that she has been on in this parliament. I have just arrived—I just got off the plane from Brisbane—so I haven't heard all of the words before. So I do apologise if I'm going to craft something that is a little bit personal.

Sadly, for me, 2023 has been a year of death. On Friday, I was at the funeral for my sister-in-law up in Cairns. On Thursday, I'm going to a funeral up in Toowoomba. So death is obviously the topic for the day. Obviously, we're talking about the life of Peta Murphy, but the obverse of that is obviously the death of Peta Murphy and the absence of Peta Murphy. It's why we're looking at flowers rather than that cheeky smile and that person that we have loved so much. I say 'a year of death' because my father passed away this year and we conducted the funeral, and then, about two weeks later, another branch member died, and we were at the same funeral home sitting in the same chairs, basically, hearing about two different lives. They were the same age, 87. I got to compare two completely different lives—my father's life and then this branch member, who was a member of the AMWU and devoted all of his life to other people. That's how I see Peta Murphy—someone who devoted all of her life to other people. I'm going to quote Confucius, which is always dangerous, but there's a quote that says:
We have two lives, and the second begins when we realise we only have one.

I knew Peta when she was Minister O'Connor's chief of staff. I dealt with her then, and then we saw her come into this party, into this parliament, where she wanted to make a difference. People do make choices about what sort of life they will live, as I saw from my father and Ron Keating. You can either devote yourself to people or be selfish. Obviously, if you want to be selfish, don't join this party. This is a party that is devoted to helping other people.

I hosted a CLC event last week here in parliament, and I know the Deputy Speaker was there. There Peta Murphy was trying to help the Australian community legal centres, because that was her background, to make a difference, to save some lives, to change a life around, to give some kid a better chance in life. I'm sure the Deputy Speaker would have heard that catch in her voice. I knew that sound because I'd heard my father have it only a few months before. There she was giving every breath in her body, literally—not a metaphor, every breath in her body—for the people of Australia, and that sums up the Peta Murphy that I'm proud to speak about.
Che Guevara, a troubling political figure but somebody I named one of my sons after—only his middle name, I should say!—said:
Words are beautiful, but action is supreme.
What greater sacrifice would it be than to come to parliament when you're as sick as Peta Murphy was but know that you can touch a few lives? That was Peta Murphy.

I think the member for Hawke spoke very accurately about how she carried the legislation in response to gambling. She was educated and informed, and she brought people along. In my electorate, the poker machines aren't around the booths that vote blue; they're around the booths that vote red. Poker machines change the lives of the poorest people especially, and Peta knew that. She was passionate about so many things. Apparently, she liked squash, but that probably hasn't been mentioned today, I imagine! That might be news to people! Peta Murphy was one of the most selfless people you could meet, and I assume that everyone has spoken about her courage. I know the shadow minister at the table, Mr Chester, has spoken about it before. He was lucky enough to spend time in New York with her. Unfortunately, Peta had to spend time with him! There are two sides to every story, I guess!
An honourable member interjecting—

Mr PERRETT: No, that would have been a special time. Obviously, all of us come to this parliament because we are passionate about changing lives. Occasionally you do meet some people who are here for selfish reasons, but mostly people come here to help their tribe, whatever that tribe may be. And Peta Murphy spent all her life doing that—trying to help her tribe. Obviously, we all die alone, but while we are alive how we live our life is how we're judged, and Peta Murphy will be judged as both courageous and selfless—and good company as well.

I'm going to finish as I started. I said this is the year of death for me. My favourite author—sorry, he was my favourite living author; he's now dead. Cormac McCarthy also died this year, and there's a quote from him that I'm going to finish with. He said, 'In the end you can escape everything but yourself.' I think Peta knew that, more than any of us, in the last four years as she took that journey by herself. She knew: 'I'm not going to go inside myself. I'm going to help as many people as possible and that will be a legacy.' Isn't that a magnificent, shining legacy?

Our grand, eloquent words have their place, but the deeds that came from Peta Murphy will be an inspiration for many people, for another member of parliament in the future. Vale, Peta Murphy. May she rest in peace.
The SPEAKER: As a mark of respect for the memory of Peta Jan Murphy, I ask all present to rise in their places.

span.span: Honourable members having stood in their places—

p.span: The SPEAKER: I thank the House.
Debate adjourned.
The SPEAKER: As a mark of respect for the memory of Peta Jan Murphy, the sitting is suspended. The chair will be resumed in 30 minutes.
COMMITTEES
Intelligence and Security Joint Committee
Reference

The SPEAKER (21:27): I have received advice from the Senate informing the House of a resolution agreed to by the Senate, referring the following matter to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Intelligence and Security, for inquiry and report by 14 March 2024: the operation, effectiveness and implications of the amendments made by the Australian Citizenship Amendment (Citizenship Repudiation) Bill 2023.

National Disability Insurance Scheme Joint Committee
Membership

The SPEAKER (21:27): I have received advice from the Senate informing the House that Senator Askew has been discharged from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Law Enforcement and Senator Sharma has been appointed as a member of the committee; and that Senator Reynolds has been discharged from the Joint Standing Committee on the National Disability Insurance Scheme and Senator Sharma has been appointed as a member of the committee.
BILLS

subdebateinfo.title: Public Health (Tobacco and Other Products) (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2023, Australian Citizenship Amendment (Citizenship Repudiation) Bill 2023, Counter-Terrorism Legislation Amendment (Prohibited Hate Symbols and Other Measures) Bill 2023, Interactive Gambling Amendment (Credit and Other Measures) Bill 2023

p.span: Public Health (Tobacco and Other Products) (Consequential Amendments and Transitional Provisions) Bill 2023
Australian Citizenship Amendment (Citizenship Repudiation) Bill 2023
Counter-Terrorism Legislation Amendment (Prohibited Hate Symbols and Other Measures) Bill 2023
Interactive Gambling Amendment (Credit and Other Measures) Bill 2023
Messages received from the Senate returning the bills without amendment.
Infrastructure Australia Amendment (Independent Review) Bill 2023
Consideration of Senate Message
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered immediately.
Schedule 1, page 3 (after line 12), after item 2, insert:

span.span: 2A Section 3 (at the end of paragraph (d) of the definition of

p.span: Add "and".

span.span: 2B Section 3 (after paragraph (d) of the definition of

p.span: Insert:
(e) social infrastructure;
Insert:
social infrastructure means facilities, spaces, services or networks that support quality of life and wellbeing of communities.
Schedule 1, item 3, page 3 (after line 22), after paragraph 5(c), insert:
(d) to assess, and report on, projects relating to nationally significant infrastructure in accordance with section 5DA;
Schedule 1, item 4, page 4 (after line 10), at the end of section 5A, add:
(4) Infrastructure Australia must cause a copy of an audit prepared under this section to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days of that House after the audit is finalised.
Schedule 1, item 4, page 5 (after line 8), after subsection 5B(8), insert:
(8A) In performing the function mentioned in subsection (6) in relation to a proposal, Infrastructure Australia must consider what impacts the proposal, if carried out, would have on:
(a) Australia's net greenhouse gas emissions, as reported in national inventory reports in accordance with:
(i) the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change, done at New York on 9 May 1992, as amended and in force for Australia from time to time; and
(ii) the Paris Agreement, done at Paris on 12 December 2015, as amended and in force for Australia from time to time; and
(b) the achievement of Australia's greenhouse gas emissions reduction targets; and
(c) any policy issues arising from climate change that Infrastructure Australia considers relevant to the proposal.

Note: The United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change is in Australian Treaty Series 1994 No. 2 ([1994] ATS 2) and the Paris Agreement is in Australian Treaty Series 2016 No. 24 ([2016] ATS 24). They could in 2023 be viewed in the Australian Treaty Series Library on the AustLII website (www.austlii.edu.au).
Schedule 1, item 4, page 5 (after line 14), at the end of section 5B, add:
(10) Infrastructure Australia must cause a copy of the following documents to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days of that House after the document is finalised:
(a) the national planning and assessment framework mentioned in subsection (1);
(b) the summaries mentioned in subsection (9).
Schedule 1, item 4, page 6 (after line 13), at the end of section 5C, add:

(7) Infrastructure Australia must cause a copy of an Infrastructure Priority List and an Infrastructure Plan to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days of that House after the document is finalised.
Schedule 1, item 4, page 7 (after line 29), after section 5D, insert:

span.span: assessments of certain nationally significant infrastructure projects without prior evaluation

p.span: (1) For the purposes of paragraph 5(d), Infrastructure Australia has the function of assessing, and reporting on, projects covered by subsection (2).
(2) A project is covered by this subsection if:
(a) it is a project for investment in, or enhancements to, nationally significant infrastructure; and
(b) the project involves expenditure by or on behalf of the Commonwealth; and
(c) the Commonwealth Government's total expenditure involved in the project is more than $250 million; and
(d) the Commonwealth Government has committed to the project without prior evaluation (or endorsement of evaluation) of a proposal for the project by Infrastructure Australia.

(3) Infrastructure Australia must ensure that assessments under this section are conducted at least once in each financial year beginning on or after the commencement of this section and prepare a report on the assessment.
(4) Infrastructure Australia must cause a copy of the report on the assessment under subsection (3) to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days after it has been finalised.
(5) Infrastructure Australia may conduct other assessments under this section, and prepare reports on those assessments, on its own initiative.

(6) Infrastructure Australia must cause a copy of the report on the assessment mentioned in subsection (5) to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 10 sitting days after it has been finalised.
(7) The regulations may prescribe matters relating to the conduct of assessments under this section.
Schedule 1, item 4, page 7 (after line 29), after section 5D, insert:
(1) Infrastructure Australia must, during each financial year, prepare and give to the Minister the following:
(a) an annual budget statement to inform the annual Commonwealth budget process on infrastructure investment; and

(b) an annual performance statement on the performance outcomes being achieved by States, Territories and local government authorities in relation to the infrastructure investment program and existing project initiatives funded by the Commonwealth.
(2) Infrastructure Australia must cause each annual statement to be:
(a) tabled in both Houses of the Parliament no later than 14 days prior to the scheduled public release of the annual Commonwealth budget each year; and
(b) published on Infrastructure Australia's website as soon as practicable after the annual statement is tabled in the Parliament.
Schedule 1, item 22, page 12 (after line 25), after subsection 8(2), insert:

(2A) In appointing the Commissioners, the Minister must ensure that at least one of the Commissioners has a substantial connection to, or substantial experience in, a regional area through business, industry or community involvement.
Ms CATHERINE KING (Ballarat—Minister for Infrastructure, Transport, Regional Development and Local Government) (21:29): I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
Question agreed to.
Economic Inclusion Advisory Committee Bill 2023
Consideration of Senate Message
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered immediately.
Clause 8, page 6 (lines 20 to 27), omit subclause 8(6), substitute:

(6) The Joint Ministers may, by written notice to the Chair, direct the Committee to ensure that a particular report under this section at least addresses specified matters mentioned in subsection (2).
Clause 8, page 7 (line 4), after "website", insert "at least 14 days before the Commonwealth Government budget is delivered in the House of Representatives".
Clause 19, page 11 (lines 21 to 23), omit the clause, substitute:
(1) The Minister may terminate the appointment of a member of the Committee:
(a) for misbehaviour; or
(b) if the member is unable to perform the duties of the member's office because of physical or mental incapacity.
(2) The Minister may terminate the appointment of a member of the Committee if:
(a) the member:
(i) becomes bankrupt; or
(ii) applies to take the benefit of any law for the relief of bankrupt or insolvent debtors; or
(iii) compounds with the member's creditors; or
(b) the member is absent, except on leave of absence, from 3 consecutive meetings of the Committee; or
(c) the member fails, without reasonable excuse, to comply with section 16 (disclosure of interests to Joint Ministers) or section 17 (disclosure of interests to Committee).

(3) The Minister may terminate the appointment of a member of the Committee if the Minister is satisfied that, because of a change of circumstances occurring after the member's appointment, the member is no longer a representative of the kind covered by subsection 11(2).
Page 13 (after line 12), at the end of Part 2, add:

span.span: Ministers to attend meetings and provide advice or assistance

p.span: (1) The Minister is to attend 1 meeting of the Committee each financial year.
(2) The Treasurer is to attend 1 meeting of the Committee each financial year.
(3) The Joint Ministers:
(a) may provide any reasonable advice or assistance requested by the Chair for the purposes of the performance of the Committee's function; but
(b) must not take part in any decision of the Committee about matters or advice to be included by the Committee in a report under section 8.
Clause 28, page 15 (lines 4 and 5), omit "5 years", substitute "3 years".
Mrs ELLIOT (Richmond—Assistant Minister for Social Services and Assistant Minister for the Prevention of Family Violence) (21:30): I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.
The SPEAKER: The question is that the amendments be agreed to.

body.p:
The House divided. [21:34]
(The Speaker—Hon. Milton Dick)

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Amendment (Bridging Visa Conditions and Other Measures) Bill 2023

p.span: Migration Amendment (Bridging Visa Conditions and Other Measures) Bill 2023
Consideration of Senate Message
Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be considered immediately.
(1) Title, page 1 (line 1), omit "the Migration Act1958", substitute "the law relating to migration, and to protect the Australian community from serious offenders".
(2) Clause 1, page 1 (line 5), omit "Amendment (Bridging Visa Conditions", substitute "and Other Legislation Amendment (Bridging Visas, Serious Offenders".
(3) Schedule 1, heading, page 3 (line 1), after "Amendments", insert "relating to bridging visas etc.".
(4) Schedule 1, page 3 (before line 4), before item 1, insert:
Insert:

span.span: 76AA Effect of community safety order on visa held by non-citizen etc.

p.span: (1) This section applies if:
(a) a community safety order is made in relation to a non-citizen; and
(b) the order comes into force at a particular time (the relevant time).

span.span: Non-citizen who holds a visa (other than a criminal justice visa) at the relevant time

p.span: (2) If the non-citizen holds a visa (other than a criminal justice visa) at the relevant time, then, despite any other provision of this Act or the regulations, the following apply:
(a) that visa ceases to be in effect at the relevant time;
(b) the non-citizen is taken, immediately after the relevant time, to have been granted a Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa (the BVR visa);
(c) the BVR visa is taken to come into effect as soon as it is taken to be granted under paragraph (b).
Note: The visa period for the visa mentioned in paragraph (a) ends at the relevant time and the visa period for the BVR visa begins when it is taken to be granted.

span.span: Non-citizen who holds a criminal justice visa at the relevant time

p.span: (a) the non-citizen holds a criminal justice visa at the relevant time; and
(b) the criminal justice visa ceases to be in effect at a particular time (the cessation time) during the period in which the community safety order is in force in relation to the non-citizen;
then, despite any other provision of this Act or the regulations, the following apply:
(c) the non-citizen is taken, immediately after the cessation time, to have been granted a Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa (the BVR visa);
(d) the BVR visa is taken to come into effect as soon as it is taken to be granted under paragraph (c).
Note: The visa period for the BVR visa begins when it is taken to be granted.

span.span: Matters relating to the BVR visa taken to be granted to the non-citizen

p.span: (4) Subject to subsections (6) and (7), this Act and the regulations apply, after the commencement of this section, in relation to the BVR visa that is taken to be granted under paragraph (2)(b) or (3)(c) (as the case may be) in the same way as they would apply in relation to a Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa granted under the regulations.

(5) Without limiting subsection (4), the following provisions of the regulations, as in force at the time the BVR visa is taken to be granted under paragraph (2)(b) or (3)(c) (as the case may be), apply in relation to the BVR visa:
(a) a provision specifying when a Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa is in effect;
(b) a provision prescribing that a Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa permits the visa holder to remain in Australia;
(c) a provision specifying the conditions to which a Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa that is taken to be granted under paragraph (2)(b) or (3)(c) (as the case may be) is subject.
(6) The non-citizen's BVR visa must not be subject to either of the following conditions:
(a) a condition requiring the non-citizen to remain, between certain times of a day, at a particular address for the non-citizen for the day;
(b) a condition requiring the non-citizen to wear a monitoring device.

span.span: Minister must not do certain things while the
community safety order is in force

p.span: (7) The Minister must not do either of the following at any time while the community safety order made in relation to the non-citizen is in force:
(a) invite the non-citizen, for the purposes of the regulations, to apply for another Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa;
(b) grant (whether or not on application) the non-citizen another Subclass 070 (Bridging (Removal Pending)) visa under the regulations.

span.span: Inconsistency between the community safety order and the BVR visa

p.span: (a) the community safety order that is in force in relation to the non-citizen is a community safety supervision order; and
(b) at a particular time, one or more conditions (the supervision order conditions) are imposed on the non-citizen by the community safety supervision order; and
(c) at that time, a condition to which the non-citizen's BVR visa is subject is inconsistent, in whole or in part, with any of the supervision order conditions;
then, despite subsections (4) and (5), the BVR visa is to be taken, at that time, not to be subject to that condition to the extent of any such inconsistency.
(a) the community safety order made in relation to the non-citizen is a community safety detention order; and
(b) the non-citizen is unable, at a particular time, to comply with a condition to which the non-citizen's BVR visa is subject; and
(c) the non-citizen is unable to comply with the condition only because the community safety detention order is in force in relation to the non-citizen at that time;
then, despite subsections (4) and (5), the BVR visa is to be taken, at that time, not to be subject to that condition.
(10) Subsections (8) and (9) do not apply at any time while the community safety order made in relation to the non-citizen is suspended.
(11) In this section:
community safety detention order has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
community safety order means a community safety detention order or a community safety supervision order.
community safety supervision order has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
monitoring device means any electronic device capable of being used to determine or monitor the location of a person or an object or the status of an object.
(5) Page 8 (after line 21), at the end of the bill, add:
Insert:
(dada) decisions of the Immigration Minister under Division 395 of the Criminal Code;
Add:
; (d) a condition imposed on a person by a community safety supervision order under Division 395 of the Criminal Code (community safety orders);
(e) action covered by any of subsections 395.17(2) to (5) of the Criminal Code (actions relating to electronic monitoring).
Omit "or 105A", substitute ", 105A or 395".
Insert:

span.span: Monitoring of compliance with community safety supervision orders etc.

p.span: This Part affects how Part IAAB operates, so that that Part (with some modifications set out in this Part) also applies in relation to community safety supervision orders made under Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
In this Part:
community safety supervision order has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
Part 9.10 object means the protection of the community from serious harm by addressing the unacceptable risk of a serious offender committing a serious violent or sexual offence.
serious offender has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
serious violent or sexual offence has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.

span.span: 3ZZUHC Application of Part IAAB to community safety supervision orders

p.span: (1) Part IAAB (other than section 3ZZJA or 3ZZJB) applies as if:
(a) a reference to a Part 5.3 supervisory order included a reference to a community safety supervision order; and
(b) a reference to a Part 5.3 object included a reference to a Part 9.10 object.
(2) Subsection 3ZZOA(4) applies as if the following paragraph were inserted after paragraph (b) of that subsection:
(c) in relation to a community safety supervision order—the possibility that the person has committed, is committing, or will commit, a serious violent or sexual offence;
(3) Paragraph 3ZZOA(5)(l) applies as if the following subparagraph were inserted before subparagraph (i) of that paragraph:
(ia) a community safety supervision order; or
(4) Subsection 3ZZOA(5) applies as if the following paragraph were inserted after paragraph (q) of that subsection:
(qa) for a community safety supervision order:
(i) specify when the community safety supervision order comes into force; and
(ii) specify the end of the period during which the community safety supervision order is in force; and
(5) Subsection 3ZZOB(4) applies as if the following paragraph were inserted after paragraph (c) of that subsection:
(d) in relation to a community safety supervision order—the possibility that the person has committed, is committing, or will commit, a serious violent or sexual offence;
(6) Paragraph 3ZZOB(5)(j) applies as if the following subparagraph were inserted before subparagraph (i) of that paragraph:
(ia) a community safety supervision order; or
(7) Subsection 3ZZOB(5) applies as if the following paragraph were inserted after paragraph (o) of that subsection:
(oa) for a community safety supervision order:
(i) specify when the community safety supervision order comes into force; and
(ii) specify the end of the period during which the community safety supervision order is in force; and
(8) Paragraph 3ZZOD(1)(b) applies as if the following subparagraph were inserted after subparagraph (iii) of that paragraph:
(iiia) the community safety supervision order is revoked and no further community safety supervision order is made in relation to the serious offender;

span.span: 5 At the end of Chapter 9 of the

p.span: Add:
The object of this Division is to protect the community from serious harm by providing that non-citizens who:
(a) pose an unacceptable risk of committing serious violent or sexual offences; and
(b) have no real prospect of their removal from Australia becoming practicable in the reasonably foreseeable future;
are subject to:
(c) a community safety detention order; or
(d) a community safety supervision order.
(1) In this Division:
AFP member means:
(a) a member of the Australian Federal Police (within the meaning of the Australian Federal Police Act 1979); or
(b) a special member of the Australian Federal Police (within the meaning of that Act).
Commonwealth law enforcement officer has the meaning given by Part 7.8.
community safety detention order means an order made under subsection 395.12(1).
community safety order means a community safety detention order or a community safety supervision order.
community safety order decision means:
(a) a decision on an application for a community safety order; or
(b) a decision on an application to vary a community safety supervision order; or
(c) a decision in a review of a community safety order to affirm, revoke or vary the order; or
(d) a decision made under section 395.34 (when a serious offender is unable to engage a legal representative).
Note: See also subsection (4).
community safety order proceeding means a proceeding under Subdivision C, D or E.
community safety supervision order means an order made under subsection 395.13(1).
detained in custody has the meaning given by subsection (2).
detained in custody in a prison has the meaning given by subsection (3).
exemption condition has the meaning given by subsection 395.15(2).
immigration detention has the same meaning as in the Migration Act 1958.
Immigration Minister means the Minister administering the Migration Act 1958.
lawyer means a person enrolled as a legal practitioner of a federal court or the Supreme Court of a State or Territory.
monitoring device means any electronic device capable of being used to determine or monitor the location of a person or an object or the status of an object.
Note: See also the definition of related monitoring equipment in this subsection.
non-citizen means a person who is not an Australian citizen.
personal information has the same meaning as in the Privacy Act 1988.
police officer means:
(a) an AFP member; or
(b) a member (however described) of a police force of a State or Territory.
premises includes a place, an aircraft, a vehicle and a vessel.
prison includes any gaol, lock-up or remand centre.
related monitoring equipment, in relation to a monitoring device, means any electronic equipment necessary for operating the monitoring device.
relevant expert means any of the following persons who is competent to assess the risk of a serious offender committing a serious violent or sexual offence:
(a) a person who is:
(i) registered as a medical practitioner under a law of a State or Territory; and
(ii) a fellow of the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists;
(b) any other person registered as a medical practitioner under a law of a State or Territory;
(c) a person registered as a psychologist under a law of a State or Territory;
(d) any other expert.
reside includes reside temporarily.
residence includes temporary residence.
senior AFP member means:
(a) the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police; or
(b) a Deputy Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police; or
(c) an AFP member of, or above, the rank of Superintendent.
serious foreign violent or sexual offence means an offence against a law of a foreign country, or of part of a foreign country, where:
(a) it is an offence punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period, or maximum period, of at least 7 years; and
(b) it is constituted by conduct that, if engaged in in Australia, would constitute an offence against a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory; and
(c) the particular conduct constituting the offence involved, involves or would involve, as the case requires:
(i) loss of a person's life or serious risk of loss of a person's life; or
(ii) serious personal injury or serious risk of serious personal injury; or
(iii) sexual assault; or
(iv) sexual assault involving a person under 16; or
(v) the production, publication, possession, supply or sale of, or other dealing in, child abuse material (within the meaning of Part 10.6); or
(vi) consenting to or procuring the employment of a child, or employing a child, in connection with material referred to in subparagraph (v); or
(vii) acts done in preparation for, or to facilitate, the commission of a sexual offence against a person under 16.
serious offender has the meaning given by subsections 395.5(1) and (2).
Note: This definition is affected by section 395.37.
serious violent or sexual offence means an offence against a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory where:
(a) it is an offence punishable by imprisonment for life or for a period, or maximum period, of at least 7 years; and
(b) the particular conduct constituting the offence involved, involves or would involve, as the case requires:
(i) loss of a person's life or serious risk of loss of a person's life; or
(ii) serious personal injury or serious risk of serious personal injury; or
(iii) sexual assault; or
(iv) sexual assault involving a person under 16; or
(v) the production, publication, possession, supply or sale of, or other dealing in, child abuse material (within the meaning of Part 10.6); or
(vi) consenting to or procuring the employment of a child, or employing a child, in connection with material referred to in subparagraph (v); or
(vii) acts done in preparation for, or to facilitate, the commission of a sexual offence against a person under 16.

specified authority: a person, or person in a class of persons, is a specified authority for a requirement or condition in a community safety supervision order in relation to another person (the subject) if:
(a) the person or class is any of the following:
(i) a police officer, or class of police officer;
(ii) if the requirement or condition relates to electronic monitoring—a person, or class of person, who is involved in electronically monitoring the subject;
(iii) for any requirement or condition in the order—any other person, or class of person; and
(b) the Court making the order is satisfied that the person or class is appropriate in relation to the requirement or condition; and
(c) the person or class is specified in the order.
(2) A person is detained in custody if the person is detained in custody under a law of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory.

(3) A person is detained in custody in a prison if the person is detained in custody in a gaol, lock-up or remand centre, including under a community safety detention order. However, a person is not detained in custody in a prison if the person is in immigration detention in a gaol, lock-up or remand centre.

(4) To avoid doubt, a decision on an application to a Supreme Court of a State or Territory for a community safety order is not made until the Court determines the application in accordance with section 395.10.
This Division is not intended to exclude or limit the concurrent operation of any law of a State or Territory.

span.span: 395.4 Regulations may modify operation of this Division to deal with interaction between this Division and State and Territory laws

p.span: (1) The regulations may modify the operation of this Division so that:
(a) provisions of this Division do not apply to a matter that is dealt with by a law of a State or Territory specified in the regulations; or
(b) no inconsistency arises between the operation of a provision of this Division and the operation of a State or Territory law specified in the regulations.
(2) Without limiting subsection (1), regulations made for the purposes of that subsection may provide that the provision of this Division does not apply to:
(a) a person specified in the regulations; or
(b) a body specified in the regulations; or
(c) circumstances specified in the regulations; or
(d) a person or body specified in the regulations in the circumstances specified in the regulations.
(3) In this section:
matter includes act, omission, body, person or thing.

span.span: 395.5 Who a community safety order may apply to and effect of community safety orders

p.span: (1) A community safety order may be made under section 395.12 or 395.13 in relation to a person (the serious offender) if:
(a) the person has been convicted of a serious violent or sexual offence; and
(b) the person is a non-citizen; and
(c) there is no real prospect of removal of the person from Australia becoming practicable in the reasonably foreseeable future; and
(d) a subsection of section 395.6 provides that the order may be made in relation to the person; and
(e) the person is at least 18 years old.
Note: Before making the order, a Court must be satisfied of certain matters under section 395.12 or 395.13.
(2) A community safety order may be made under section 395.12 or 395.13 in relation to a person (the serious offender) if:
(a) the person has been convicted of a serious foreign violent or sexual offence; and
(b) the person is a non-citizen; and
(c) there is no real prospect of removal of the person from Australia becoming practicable in the reasonably foreseeable future; and
(d) a subsection of section 395.6 provides that the order may be made in relation to the person; and
(e) the person is at least 18 years old.
Note: Before making the order, a Court must be satisfied of certain matters under section 395.12 or 395.13.

span.span: Effect of community safety detention order

p.span: (3) The effect of a community safety detention order is to commit the person to detention in a prison for the period the order is in force.
Note 1: The period must not be more than 3 years (see subsection 395.12(5)).
Note 2: See also:
(a) section 395.41 (detention under the Migration Act 1958); and
(b) section 395.42 (effect of prison detention on community safety order); and
(c) subsection 395.47(2) (arrangements with States and Territories); and
(d) section 395.50 (effect of community safety detention orders on bail or parole laws).

span.span: Effect of a community safety supervision order

p.span: (4) The effect of a community safety supervision order is to impose on the person, for the period the order is in force, conditions contravention of which is an offence.
Note 1: The period must not be more than 3 years (see paragraph 395.13(5)(d)).
Note 2: See also sections 395.41 (detention under the Migration Act 1958) and 395.42 (effect of prison detention on community safety order).

span.span: Person is detained in custody in a prison

p.span: (1) A community safety order may be made in relation to a person if the person is detained in custody in a prison serving:
(a) a sentence of imprisonment for a serious violent or sexual offence; or
(b) a sentence of imprisonment for any other offence.
(2) A community safety order may be made in relation to a person if the person is in the community.

span.span: Community safety detention order is in force

p.span: (3) A community safety order may be made in relation to a person if a community safety detention order is in force in relation to the person.

span.span: 395.7 Treatment of a serious offender in a prison under a community safety detention order

p.span: (1) A serious offender who is detained in custody in a prison under a community safety detention order must be treated in a way that is appropriate to the offender's status as a person who is not serving a sentence of imprisonment, subject to any reasonable requirements necessary to maintain:
(a) the management, security or good order of the prison; and
(b) the safe custody or welfare of the offender or any prisoners; and
(c) the safety and protection of the community.
(2) The offender must not be accommodated or detained in the same area or unit of the prison as persons who are in prison for the purpose of serving sentences of imprisonment unless:
(a) it is reasonably necessary for the purposes of rehabilitation, treatment, work, education, general socialisation or other group activities; or
(b) it is necessary for the security or good order of the prison or the safe custody or welfare of the offender or prisoners; or
(c) it is necessary for the safety and protection of the community; or
(d) the offender elects to be so accommodated or detained.
(3) This section does not apply if the offender is serving a sentence of imprisonment.

span.span: 395.8 Applying for a community safety order

p.span: (1) The Immigration Minister, or a legal representative of the Immigration Minister, (the applicant) may apply to a Supreme Court of a State or Territory for either of the following:
(a) a community safety detention order in relation to a serious offender;
(b) a community safety supervision order in relation to a serious offender.
Note: The court may make a community safety supervision order under section 395.13 even if a community safety detention order is applied for.

(2) The Immigration Minister must ensure that reasonable inquiries are made to ascertain any facts known to any Commonwealth law enforcement officer that would reasonably be regarded as supporting a finding that:
(a) if the application is for a community safety detention order—neither a community safety detention order nor a community safety supervision order should be made in relation to the offender; or
(b) if the application is for a community safety supervision order—the community safety supervision order should not be made in relation to the offender.
(3) The application must:
(a) include any report or other document that the applicant intends, at the time of the application, to rely on in relation to the application; and
(b) include:
(i) a copy of any material in the possession of the applicant; and
(ii) a statement of any facts that the applicant is aware of;

that would reasonably be regarded as supporting a finding that the order or orders mentioned in paragraph (2)(a) or (b) (as the case requires) should not be made, except any information, material or facts that are likely to be protected by public interest immunity (whether the claim for public interest immunity is to be made by the Immigration Minister or any other person); and
(c) include information about the offender's age; and
(d) if the offender is a holder under the Migration Act 1958 of a visa that is subject to one or more conditions—specify the conditions; and
(e) request that the order be in force for a specified period; and
(f) if the application is for a community safety supervision order—include the following material:
(i) a copy of the proposed conditions;
(ii) an explanation as to why each of the proposed conditions should be imposed on the offender;

(iii) if the Immigration Minister is aware of any facts relating to why any of those conditions should not be imposed on the offender—a statement of those facts, except any facts that are likely to be protected by public interest immunity (whether the claim for public interest immunity is to be made by the Immigration Minister or any other person);
(iv) if the offender is subject to an order under a law of a State or Territory that is equivalent to a community safety order—a copy of that order; and
(g) if a report was obtained under section 395.43 in relation to the offender—include a copy of the report.
Note 1: For paragraph (3)(e), the period must not be more than 3 years (see subsection 395.12(5) and paragraph 395.13(5)(d)).
Note 2: Evidence may also be adduced later under section 395.28.
Note 3: A copy of the application must be given to the serious offender under section 395.29.

span.span: 395.9 Appointment of and assessment by relevant expert

p.span: (1) If an application for a community safety order is made under section 395.8 to a Supreme Court of a State or Territory in relation to a serious offender, the Court must hold a preliminary hearing to determine whether to appoint one or more relevant experts.
(2) The hearing must be held within 28 days after a copy of the application is given to the offender under subsection 395.29(2).

(3) The Court may, either at the preliminary hearing or at any later time in the proceeding, appoint one or more relevant experts if the Court considers that doing so is likely to materially assist the Court in deciding whether to make a community safety order in relation to the offender.
(4) The Immigration Minister or the offender, or a legal representative of the Immigration Minister or the offender, may nominate one or more relevant experts for the purposes of subsection (3).
(5) The relevant expert who is appointed must:
(a) conduct an assessment of the risk of the offender committing a serious violent or sexual offence; and
(b) provide a report of the expert's assessment to the Court, the Immigration Minister and the offender.
Note: For giving documents to a serious offender who is detained in custody, see section 395.33.
(6) The offender must attend the assessment.
Note: The assessment may be conducted over a number of sessions.
(7) The answer to a question or information given at the assessment, and answering a question or giving information at the assessment, are not admissible in evidence against the offender in:
(a) any criminal proceedings, except any proceedings relating to sentencing for an offence against this Division (including any appeal in relation to those proceedings); or
(b) any civil proceedings against the offender, except proceedings under this Division (including any appeal in relation to those proceedings).
(8) The Court must ensure that the effect of subsections (6), (7) and (11) is explained to the offender.
(9) The expert's report may include any one or more of the following matters:
(a) the expert's assessment of the risk of the offender committing a serious violent or sexual offence;
(b) reasons for that assessment;

(c) the pattern or progression to date of behaviour on the part of the offender in relation to serious violent or sexual offences, and an indication of the nature of any likely future behaviour on the offender's part in relation to serious violent or sexual offences;

(d) efforts made to date by the offender to address the causes of the offender's behaviour in relation to serious violent or sexual offences, including whether the offender has actively participated in any rehabilitation or treatment programs;
(e) if the offender has participated in any rehabilitation or treatment programs—whether or not this participation has had a positive effect on the offender;
(f) any relevant background of the offender, including developmental and social factors;
(g) factors that might increase or decrease any risks that have been identified of the offender committing a serious violent or sexual offence;
