(6AA) In the case of a computer that is subject to a Part 9.10 warrant that is a computer access warrant, the eligible Judge or nominated AAT member may grant the assistance order if the eligible Judge or nominated AAT member is satisfied that:
(a) there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that access to the data held in the computer would be likely to substantially assist in:
(i) if the computer access warrant was issued to determine whether to apply for a Part 9.10 order—determining whether to apply for the Part 9.10 order; or

(ii) if the computer access warrant was issued on the basis of a community safety supervision order that is in force—achieving a Part 9.10 object, or determining whether the community safety supervision order, or any succeeding community safety supervision order, has been, or is being, complied with; and
(b) the specified person is:
(i) if the warrant was issued to determine whether to apply for a Part 9.10 order—the person to whom the application relates; or
(ii) if the warrant was issued in relation to a community safety supervision order that is in force—the subject of the community safety supervision order; or
(iii) the owner or lessee of the computer; or
(iv) an employee of the owner or lessee of the computer; or
(v) a person engaged under a contract for services by the owner or lessee of the computer; or
(vi) a person who uses or has used the computer; or
(vii) a person who is or was a system administrator for the system including the computer; and
(c) the specified person has relevant knowledge of:
(i) the computer or a computer network of which the computer forms or formed a part; or
(ii) measures applied to protect data held in the computer.
Insert:
community safety detention order has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
community safety supervision order has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
Immigration Minister means the Minister administering the Migration Act 1958.
Part 9.10 object means the protection of the community from serious harm by addressing the unacceptable risk of a serious offender committing serious violent or sexual offences.
Part 9.10 order means a community safety detention order or a community safety supervision order.
Part 9.10 warrant means a warrant issued:
(a) under subsection 46(9) or (12) or 46A(2E) or (2G); or
(b) under section 48 in the circumstances mentioned in subsection 46(9) or (12).
Part 9.10 warrant agency means:
(a) a Commonwealth agency; or
(b) an eligible authority of a State that a declaration in force under section 34 authorises to apply for Part 9.10 warrants.

span.span: 6UA When a community safety supervision order is

p.span: For the purposes of this Act, a community safety supervision order is taken to be in force in relation to a person if the order has been made but the period specified in the order under paragraph 395.13(5)(d) of the Criminal Code has not yet begun.

(1) If a community safety supervision order is made in relation to a person, any later community safety supervision order in relation to the person is a succeeding community safety supervision order in relation to an earlier community safety supervision order.

(2) If 2 or more successive community safety supervision orders are made in relation to the same person, each later community safety supervision order is a succeeding community safety supervision order in relation to each earlier community safety supervision order.

p.span: Add:

span.span: 38B Agencies authorised to apply for Part 9.10 warrants

p.span: (1) This section applies to a declaration made under section 34 in relation to an eligible authority of a State.
(2) When the Minister makes the declaration, the Minister must, in the declaration, authorise the eligible authority to apply for Part 9.10 warrants if:
(a) the Premier of the State requests that the eligible authority be so authorised; and
(b) the Minister is satisfied as mentioned in subsection (4) of this section.
(3) The Minister must amend the declaration to authorise the eligible authority to apply for Part 9.10 warrants if:
(a) the declaration does not already so authorise the eligible authority; and
(b) the Premier of the State requests that the eligible authority be so authorised; and
(c) the Minister is satisfied as mentioned in subsection (4).

span.span: authorised to apply for a Part 9.10 warrant

p.span: (4) For the purposes of paragraph (2)(b) or (3)(c), the Minister must be satisfied that the law of the State makes satisfactory provision:

(a) imposing on the chief officer of the eligible authority requirements corresponding to the requirements that paragraphs 80(f) and (g) and 81(1)(h) and subsection 81(2), so far as that subsection relates to paragraph 81(1)(h), impose on the chief officer of a Commonwealth agency; and
(b) imposing on the chief officer of the eligible authority requirements corresponding to the requirements that section 59C imposes on the chief officer of a Commonwealth agency; and

(c) giving an authority of the State powers corresponding to those that subsections 83(3) and 84(2) and sections 85 and 85B give to the Ombudsman, if the authority of the State receives a notice from the eligible authority because of the requirements mentioned in paragraph (b) of this subsection; and

(d) requiring an authority of the State that has made an inspection of the eligible authority's records under the powers mentioned in paragraph (c) to report in writing to the responsible Minister about the results of the inspection; and

(e) requiring the responsible Minister to give to the Minister, as soon as practicable, a copy of a report that an authority of the State gives to the responsible Minister under a power or requirement mentioned in paragraph (c) or (d).

(5) The Minister must amend the declaration to remove the authorisation of the eligible authority to apply for Part 9.10 warrants if the Premier of the State requests the Minister to remove the authorisation.
(6) The Minister may amend the declaration to remove the authorisation of the eligible authority to apply for Part 9.10 warrants if the Minister is satisfied that:
(a) the law of the State no longer makes satisfactory provision in relation to the eligible authority as mentioned in subsection (4); or

(b) the extent of compliance with a requirement of a law of that State, being a requirement of a kind mentioned in subsection (4), has been unsatisfactory in so far as the requirement relates to the eligible authority; or

(c) the extent of compliance by the chief officer of the eligible authority, or by officers of the eligible authority, with this Act has been unsatisfactory, so far as this Act relates to Part 9.10 warrants.

(7) If the Minister amends the declaration under subsection (5) or (6), the amendment does not affect the validity of a Part 9.10 warrant issued before the amendment in response to an application by the eligible authority.

Add:

span.span: Warrant sought for community safety supervision order

p.span: (9) If a Part 9.10 warrant agency applies to an eligible Judge or nominated AAT member for a warrant in respect of a telecommunications service and the Judge or nominated AAT member is satisfied, on the basis of the information given to the Judge or nominated AAT member under this Part in connection with the application, that:
(a) Division 3 has been complied with in relation to the application; and
(b) in the case of a telephone application—because of urgent circumstances, it was necessary to make the application by telephone; and
(c) there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that a particular person is using, or is likely to use, the service; and
(d) either:
(i) a community safety supervision order is in force in relation to the particular person; or
(ii) a community safety supervision order is in force in relation to another person, and the particular person is likely to communicate with the other person using the service; and
(e) information that would be likely to be obtained by intercepting under a warrant communications made to or from the service would be likely to substantially assist in connection with:
(i) achieving a Part 9.10 object; or
(ii) determining whether the community safety supervision order, or any succeeding community safety supervision order, has been, or is being, complied with; and
(f) having regard to the matters referred to in subsection (10), and to no other matters, the Judge or nominated AAT member should issue a warrant authorising such communications to be intercepted;
the Judge or nominated AAT member may, in the Judge or member's discretion, issue such a warrant.
Note 1: Subsection (11) restricts the issuing of warrants if subparagraph (d)(ii) applies.
Note 2: For community safety supervision orders that have been made but not come into force, see section 6UA.
(10) For the purposes of subsection (9), the matters to which the Judge or nominated AAT member must have regard are:
(a) how much the privacy of any person or persons would be likely to be interfered with by intercepting under a warrant communications made to or from the service referred to in subsection (9); and
(b) how much the information referred to in paragraph (9)(e) would be likely to assist in connection with:
(i) achieving a Part 9.10 object; or
(ii) determining whether the community safety supervision order, or any succeeding community safety supervision order, has been, or is being, complied with; and
(c) to what extent methods for:
(i) achieving a Part 9.10 object; or
(ii) determining whether the community safety supervision order, or any succeeding community safety supervision order, has been, or is being, complied with;
that do not involve so intercepting communications have been used by, or are available to, the agency; and
(d) how much the use of such methods would be likely to assist in connection with:
(i) achieving a Part 9.10 object; or
(ii) determining whether the community safety supervision order, or any succeeding community safety supervision order, has been, or is being, complied with; and
(e) how much the use of such methods would be likely to prejudice:
(i) achieving a Part 9.10 object; or
(ii) determining whether the community safety supervision order, or any succeeding community safety supervision order, has been, or is being, complied with;
whether because of delay or for any other reason; and

(f) whether intercepting under a warrant communications made to or from the service referred to in subsection (9) would be the method that is likely to have the least interference with any person's privacy; and
(g) the possibility that the person in relation to whom the order is in force has committed, is committing, or will commit a serious violent or sexual offence; and
(h) the possibility that the person in relation to whom the order is in force:
(i) has contravened, is contravening or will contravene the community safety supervision order; or
(ii) will contravene a succeeding community safety supervision order; and
(i) in relation to an application by an interception agency of Victoria—any submissions made by the Victorian PIM under section 44A to the Judge or nominated AAT member; and
(j) in relation to an application by an interception agency of Queensland—any submissions made by the Queensland PIM under section 45 to the Judge or nominated AAT member.
(11) The Judge or nominated AAT member must not issue a warrant in a case in which subparagraph (9)(d)(ii) applies unless the Judge or nominated AAT member is satisfied that:

(a) the agency has exhausted all other practicable methods of identifying the telecommunications services used, or likely to be used, by the person to whom the community safety supervision order referred to in subparagraph (9)(d)(ii) relates; or
(b) interception of communications made to or from a telecommunications service used or likely to be used by that person would not otherwise be possible.

(12) If a Part 9.10 warrant agency applies to an eligible Judge or nominated AAT member for a warrant in respect of a telecommunications service and the Judge or nominated AAT member is satisfied, on the basis of the information given to the Judge or nominated AAT member under this Part in connection with the application, that:
(a) Division 3 has been complied with in relation to the application; and
(b) in the case of a telephone application—because of urgent circumstances, it was necessary to make the application by telephone; and
(c) there are reasonable grounds for suspecting that a particular person is using, or is likely to use, the service; and
(d) the person is a serious offender in relation to whom an application for a Part 9.10 order could be made; and
(e) there are reasonable grounds to suspect that there is an appreciable risk of the person committing a serious violent or sexual offence; and

(f) consideration is being given, will be given, or is likely to be given, by the Immigration Minister (or a person on behalf of the Immigration Minister), as to whether to apply for a Part 9.10 order in relation to the person; and

(g) information that would be likely to be obtained by intercepting under a warrant communications made to or from the service would be likely to assist in determining whether to apply for the Part 9.10 order; and
(h) having regard to the matters referred to in subsection (13), and to no other matters, the Judge or nominated AAT member should issue a warrant authorising such communications to be intercepted;
the Judge or nominated AAT member may, in the Judge's or member's discretion, issue such a warrant.
(13) For the purposes of subsection (12), the matters to which the Judge or nominated AAT member must have regard are:
(a) how much the privacy of any person or persons would be likely to be interfered with by intercepting under a warrant communications made to or from the service referred to in subsection (12); and
(b) how much the information referred to in paragraph (12)(g) would be likely to assist in determining whether to apply for the Part 9.10 order; and

(c) to what extent methods of determining whether to apply for the Part 9.10 order that do not involve so intercepting communications have been used by, or are available to, the Immigration Minister (or a legal representative of the Immigration Minister); and
(d) how much the use of such methods would be likely to assist in determining whether to apply for the Part 9.10 order; and
(e) how much the use of such methods would be likely to prejudice determining whether to apply for the Part 9.10 order, whether because of delay or for any other reason; and
(f) in relation to an application by an interception agency of Victoria—any submissions made by the Victorian PIM under section 44A to the Judge or nominated AAT member; and
(g) in relation to an application by an interception agency of Queensland—any submissions made by the Queensland PIM under section 45 to the Judge or nominated AAT member.

(1) Division 395 of the Criminal Code, as inserted by this Schedule, applies in relation to a conviction for a serious violent or sexual offence, or a serious foreign violent or sexual offence, that occurs before, on or after the commencement of this item.

(2) The Surveillance Devices Act 2004 and the Telecommunications (Interception and Access) Act 1979, as amended by this Schedule, apply in relation to a serious offender, whether the conviction concerned occurs before, on or after the commencement of this item.

Subsections 38B(3), (5) and (6) of the Telecommunications (Interception and Access) Act 1979, as inserted by this Schedule, apply in relation to a declaration that is in force on or after the commencement of this item, whether the declaration was made before, on or after that commencement.
The amendments of the Telecommunications (Interception and Access) Act 1979 made by this Schedule apply in relation to:
(a) the making of a record of, the disclosure of or the use of information on or after the commencement of this item; and
(b) the disclosure or use of a document on or after the commencement of this item;
whether the information or document was obtained before, on or after that commencement.
Mr GILES (Scullin—Minister for Immigration, Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs) (21:39): I move:
That the amendments be agreed to.

The Migration Amendment (Bridging Visa Conditions and Other Measures) Bill 2023 proposes important amendments to the Migration Act that complement and reinforce amendments passed by the parliament on 18 October 2023.

On 8 November, in the NZYQ case, the High Court determined that NZYQ's detention was unlawful 'by reason of there having been and continuing to be no real prospect of the removal of the plaintiff from Australia in the reasonably foreseeable future'. As the Attorney-General has made clear in his statement:

In NZYQ, the High Court made a decision that did not only apply to the plaintiff in that matter. Rather, the Court set a new limit on the Parliament's power to make laws requiring or authorising the detention of any non-citizen who is relevantly in the same position as the plaintiff … As a result of the High Court's decision, the continued detention of any NZYQ-affected person would be unlawful.'
This is the reality of the High Court's decision. The government did not choose to be in this position.
Opposition members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting.

Mr GILES: This situation was imposed on us and this parliament by the High Court. Nonetheless, since the High Court's decision, we have taken swift action to deal with the court's requirement to release detainees. From the outset, we imposed strict visa conditions on the cohort, including strict reporting requirements. On 16 November we strengthened this, with the support of the coalition, to ensure that detainees are subject to electronic monitoring devices and curfews, and today, amongst other significant changes, we are legislating to provide for a new preventive detention regime. This robust preventive detention and community safety order regime is modelled on the existing high-risk terrorist laws enacted under the former government. The intent of this scheme is to capture those individuals who pose an unacceptable risk of harm in the community through committing a serious violent or sexual offence. The preventive detention regime would allow for the court to detain the worst of the worst offenders. To be clear, it would not capture all of the detainees released since the High Court decision.
This considered, measured and responsible legislation will see individuals redetained—
Mr Pike interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The member for Bowman will cease interjecting.

Mr GILES: where a court is satisfied that the person poses an unacceptable risk of committing a serious violent or sexual offence. My department has already commenced work in preparing the stages to go to applications for court orders for serious offenders. We will do so in a considered way to ensure that the applications are effective and that they are robust. And I want to make clear the very important role that states and territories will have in sharing with us the information we need to ensure that these applications have the greatest chance of success, something I'm sure all members of this parliament would wish to see.

I want to conclude by making clear that community safety is and will be our utmost priority. I want to thank the Australian Federal Police and the Australian Border Force for their hard work, alongside state and territory authorities, to keep Australians safe. Through Operation AEGIS, we are working day and night to keep the community safe. These strong laws will assist us in taking further necessary steps to protect the Australian community. I commend the bill as amended to the House.
Mr BURKE (Watson—Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Minister for the Arts and Leader of the House) (21:43): I move:
That the question be now put.
Mr Tehan: Oh, gutless, gutless! You don't even want to debate it.
The SPEAKER: The member for Wannon will resume his seat.
Opposition members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting immediately. The question is that the question be put.

body.p:
The House divided. [21:48]
(The Speaker—Hon. Milton Dick)

p.span: The SPEAKER (21:49): The question now is that the amendments be agreed to.
Question agreed to.
Mr TEHAN (Wannon) (21:50): What a shambles! What chaos! You don't even want to debate the No. 1 priority of any government: to keep the community safe—
The SPEAKER: Order! The shadow minister needs to move the amendment in his name.
Mr TEHAN: You're hiding. It's time that the Prime Minister—
Honourable members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! Just resume your seat. Leader of the House, resume your seat. The member for Wannon has the call and he will need to move the amendment circulated in his name.
Mr TEHAN: I move the amendment to the Senate amendments as circulated in my name:
(1) Page 2 (after line 11), after clause 3, insert:
(1) The Immigration Minister must prepare a statement about the following:
(a) each decision to apply for a community safety order in relation to a serious offender;
(b) each decision not to apply for a community safety order in relation to a serious offender.
(2) For the purposes of subsection (1), if:
(a) a person is a serious offender on the day this section commences and a decision to apply for a community safety order in relation to the person is not made within the next 7 days; or

(b) a person is a serious offender who is released from immigration detention on a day after the day this section commences, and a decision to apply for a community safety order in relation to the person is not made within the next 7 days;
treat the Immigration Minister as having decided on that seventh day not to apply for a community safety order in relation to the person.

span.span: Information to be included in the statement

p.span: (3) The statement about the decision relating to the serious offender must, subject to subsection (4), include the following:
(a) details of any visa held by the serious offender, including any conditions imposed on the visa;
(b) details about whether those visa conditions (if any) were considered sufficient or insufficient;
(c) details of the serious offender's immigration history, including about:
(i) any visas previously held by the serious offender; and

(ii) why there was no real prospect of the removal of the serious offender from Australia becoming practicable in the reasonably foreseeable future, when the serious offender was released from immigration detention;
(d) if the serious offender is, or has been, of character concern—details of the character concern;
(e) if the serious offender has been convicted, in Australia, of an offence—details of the offence;
(f) if the serious offender has been convicted, in a foreign country, of an offence—details of the offence (to the extent that the details are held by the Immigration Minister or the Department);
(g) details of any attempts to remove or deport the serious offender from Australia.
(4) The statement about the decision relating to the serious offender must not include:
(a) the serious offender's name, date of birth or residential address; or
(b) information that would reveal the identity of the serious offender; or
(c) information the disclosure of which would, or could reasonably be expected to, cause damage to the security, defence or international relations of the Commonwealth.

span.span: Preparation within 7 days and tabling on the next sitting day

p.span: (5) The statement about the decision relating to the serious offender must be prepared within the period of 7 days starting on the day the decision is made.
(6) The Immigration Minister must cause a copy of the statement to be tabled in each House of the Parliament on the next sitting day of that House after the end of that 7-day period.
(7) The Immigration Minister is not required to observe any requirements of the natural justice hearing rule in exercising a power or performing a function under this section.
(8) In this section:
community safety order has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
Department means the Department administered by the Immigration Minister.
immigration detention has the same meaning as in the Migration Act 1958.
Immigration Minister means the Minister administering the Migration Act 1958.
serious offender has the same meaning as in Division 395 of the Criminal Code.
What a shambles! What a chaos! The Leader of the House doesn't even know what's happening. From day one, your response to this has been appalling.
Honourable members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! The member for Wannon will pause. The Leader of the House?
Mr Burke: We have a message from the Senate—
Mr Chester interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! The member for Gippsland will pause.

Mr Burke: We have a message from the Senate advising us that they've returned a bill with amendments. We have a resolution moved by the minister that the amendments be agreed to. It was moved that that question be put and we have now dealt with the message. The message has now been dealt with.
The SPEAKER: Yes. The member for Wannon has circulated amendments in his name relevant to the Senate amendments.
Mr Burke: Mr Speaker, to the point of order, if I may?
Mr Fletcher interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! The manager will pause and then I'll hear from him.

Mr Burke: In the Senate, there's a procedure that because amendments have been circulated they're therefore before the house. What we have before the House is a message from the Senate which the House has now decided to respond to, unanimously, by agreeing to the amendments from the Senate. We have dealt with the message from the Senate. If there were to be—
Honourable members interjecting—
Mr Burke: If I may?
Opposition members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! Members on my left will pause. The manager will get the call—he'll get the call, don't worry. I will hear from the Leader of the House.

Mr Burke: If someone wishes to vary, in the ordinary course, a resolution that is a response to a message from the Senate then they have to amend the minister's motion. That is, ordinarily, the process in this House. There was no amendment before the House to the motion that was moved by the minister. The House does not go through consecutive responses to a message from the Senate; we have one response to a message from the Senate. It is, traditionally, moved by the minister, but it doesn't have to be. Once moved, sometimes that resolution can be further amended by the House. Whether something has been circulated or not can be relevant when you're dealing with consideration in detail, but I don't see how that process applies where we're dealing with a message from the Senate.
The SPEAKER: I will hear from the Manager of Opposition Business.
Mr Fletcher: The member for Wannon stood and moved his amendments. There's nothing at all inconsistent—
Government members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! Members on my right will cease interjecting.
Mr Fletcher: with the amendments that the member for Wannon has moved. It's perfectly open to the House to consider them, consistent with the procedure in standing order 160—
Honourable members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order!

Mr Fletcher: It's noteworthy that the Leader of the House has not mentioned one standing order. We know he's a bit shaky on the relations between the House and the Senate, but this is a very important point. The member for Wannon has put amendments which go to additional matters that the immigration minister should be required to deal with, and the House should consider them.
The SPEAKER: Order. Under standing order 158:
(b) The House may:
(ii) make an amendment, which shall be relevant to the Senate amendment, to any Senate amendment; …
Even though this matter has been resolved, the advice is that the member for Wannon is able to move the amendment circulated in his name.
Opposition members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting. Then the House will make a determination on that amendment, and we will resolve it.
Mr Hogan interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! The member for Page. I'm going to allow the member for Wannon to move his amendment, and then we'll deal with that.
Mr TEHAN: This would be funny, except this is about keeping the Australian people safe. This is a circus. You're failing—
The SPEAKER: The member for Wannon will pause. The member for Groom, I want silence on my left. The Leader of the House has the call.

Mr Burke: In terms of when there is agreement between the houses: agreement between the houses occurs when either the Senate agree to a bill in the form that we have sent to them or they send it back to us with amendments and we agree to those. At this point, the moment we carried that last resolution there was agreement between the houses. Agreement between the houses has now occurred. There is no further question before the House. The amendment that the member for Wannon is seeking to move is an amendment to a question that the House has already resolved. The moment we had the same position on this bill as the other place, there was agreement between the houses. Once agreement between the houses has occurred, there is no further question. Had this been an amendment to the resolution moved by the minister, it would have been moved prior to there being agreement between the houses. But once agreement between—
Opposition members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Members on my left are not helping.
Mr Burke: It is fundamental to how we have always operated that, the moment both houses have resolved to agree on a bill in the same form, the matter is done.
The SPEAKER: I'll hear from the Manager of Opposition Business.
Opposition members interjecting—
The SPEAKER: We'll deal with this in an orderly manner.

Mr Fletcher: Mr Speaker, you have made a ruling. You have given the member for Wannon the call. The appropriate course is that he should be allowed to proceed. He's moved his motion. If the Leader of the House disagrees, his only option is to move dissent in your ruling.
The SPEAKER: Just for the benefit of the House, the member for Wannon will get the call. Under standing order 158:
(a) If a House bill is returned from the Senate with amendments, the amendments shall be made available to Members and a time set for the House to consider them.
(b) The House may:
(i) agree to any Senate amendment;
(ii) make an amendment, which shall be relevant to the Senate amendment, to any Senate amendment; …
I have been through the amendment. I'm going to allow the member for Wannon to have five minutes to give his address, and then the House can deal with the amendment. The Leader of the House.
ADJOURNMENT
Mr BURKE (Watson—Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations, Minister for the Arts and Leader of the House) (21:58): I move:
That the House do now adjourn.
The SPEAKER: Order! Members on my left will cease interjecting.

span.span: A division having been called and the bells being rung

p.span: Mr Dutton: Mr Speaker, [inaudible]. It's in the standing orders that when the shadow minister has been given the call [inaudible] the shadow minister can speak [inaudible]. You've given him five minutes [inaudible] that he can be interrupted at this time, during the course of his [inaudible].
The SPEAKER: The Leader of the House can move that the House do now adjourn at any time.
Ms Collins interjecting—
Mr Chester interjecting—
The SPEAKER: Order! The Minister for Housing and Homelessness will cease interjecting. The member for Gippsland will cease interjecting.
Ms Collins interjecting—
The SPEAKER: The Minister for Housing and Homelessness is warned. The question is that the House do now adjourn.

body.p:
The House divided. [22:03]
(The Speaker—Hon. Milton Dick)

Question agreed to.
House adjourned at 22:04

p.span: NOTICES
Presentation
The following notices were given:
Ms McBain to move:

That in accordance with section 5 of the Parliament Act 1974, the House approve the following proposal for works in the Parliamentary Zone which were presented to the House on 27 November 2023, namely: Senator Susan Ryan commemorative sculpture.
Mr Burke to move:
That standing order 31 (automatic adjournment of the House) and standing order 33 (limit on business) be suspended for the sitting commencing on Thursday, 7 December 2023.
